With a privileged location, a valley crossed by rivers and surrounded by hills, Ourense has natural landscapes of great beauty that are worth exploring, starting with its rivers. Walking the banks of the Minho means to discover a world of small animals and riverside forests where to get lost, going through paths that extend along its tributaries, kilometres and kilometres of nature.\n\nIf you want more, here you have an ideal base camp to discover a province where nature becomes legend: river Sil\'s canyons, Invernadoiro Natural Park, Baixa Limia-Gerés, the snowy mountains of Peña Trevinca, and so on.

The banks of river Minho constitute the city\'s great green artery: several kilometres of lush vegetation for walking, running or cycling while admiring nature and the landscape. In the most western section, after the Millennium Bridge, we find several springs of thermal water, many of them equipped for bathing.\n\nThe route begins on the right bank of the river, in the thermal area of A Chavasqueira, the closest one to the city. The path continues to O Tinteiro, and from there to the thermal area of ​​ Muíño da Veiga with its four pools. A little further on, the Outariz Thermal Station offers beauty treatments, a sauna and two thermal circuits at very competitive prices. Also, the pools of Outariz and Burga de Canedo is the largest area of thermal activity in Ourense, which is also free.

If you ascend to the areas of Cudeiro, Vilar, Palmés or Seixalbo, you will not only enjoy breathtaking views of the city of bridges, but you will also find rural villages that still retain their traditional architecture. In their ancient paths, camouflaged among the vegetation of the Ourense forest (halfway between the Atlantic and the Mediterranean forest), hiking and cycling routes are waiting for you, ideal to enter this green Ourense, a great unknown.
Trails along the river, paths between forests, urban parks, panoramic viewpoints… get ready to ride your bike and discover spectacular landscapes surrounding the city.

Ourense is undoubtly a city related with arts. All over the year, you can assist to numerous theatre festivals, some of them are performed around the streets and some others take place in the Municipal Auditorium or the Principal Theatre.\n \nThe Principal Theatre is closely linked, in the memory of the city, to the traveling circuses that with their shows were the delight of young and old. One of the most famous in Ourense in the first decades of the 20th century was the Circo Feijóo, run by Secundino Feijóo, a native of Vilanova dos Infantes (Celanova). One of its main attractions was Mendoff, the tamer of the beasts, also captain of the cossacks, admired for his bravery and courage. One day a student asked Mendoff for his origins, and he replied, half in secret, that he was from Celanova, as his boss. But of course, it is more interesting to proclaim that the tamer was a fierce Russian.

Ourense has had few ambassadors as popular as Los Suaves, the legendary rock band led by brothers Yosi and Charly Domínguez. These musicians have always maintained a close relationship with the city, present in their songs, lyrics and disc covers, such as the legendary San Francisco Express. This feeling of rock spreads through Ourense's nightlife, in the area of "Os Viños". Here, a square bears their name.

 Following their school of rock, the city has seen the appearance of other historical bands, such as Megapearls, Mitocondrias or Cosecha Roja (today Burgas Beat). In the current scenario, we should highlight BestLife (UnderYourSeat), with a certain Anglo-Saxon influence, and Os Amigos dos Músicos, who play quality folk-pop and are regulars of Café Pop Torgal, a little café near the university area, in which are programmed first line acoustic concerts, as well as interesting seasons like the American Autumn. Especially active and punk-minded are the team in charge of El Pueblo, a venue for concerts on Hernán Cortés street, deep in the old city.

Folk music has also played a significant role in the city's music scene, notably with band Mutenrohi. They were inspired from the rich Galician musical folklore that institutions such as the Royal Bagpipe Band or the Choir of Ruada have promoted for years. Mixing traditional music with other tropical sounds and rhythms, two unforgettable bands, Lamatumbá and O Sonoro Maxín, stood out for their anthems, essential in the festivals that flood Galicia every summer.

Ourense has always had a special relationship with the world of arts and culture. At its most splendid moment, in the early 20th century, it came to be known as the "Athens of Galicia", the birthplace of the so-called Generation Nós, a group of intellectuals who led the renewal and modernization of Galician culture.

The epithet is not capricious; a very important list of writers, musicians and artists were very closely linked to the old Auria, having left their mark there.

You can enjoy some fabulous artistic works on the several museums located in the city.

A different and healthy way of getting to know Ourense is to get out of its urban centre to discover its green belt, ideal for hiking. The gentle orography invites you to take long walks through landscapes and places of great natural, historical and ethnographic interest; trails, paths and tracks that will take you through magical places.

The Mozarabic Way is the longest Galician Jacobean Way: connecting Sevilla and Santiago de Compostela while extending an ancient Roman road that linked Merida with Astorga. The pilgrim that follows the old Via de la Plata takes the detour in Granja de la Moreruela (Zamora) up to A Gudiña, where there are two routes for Santiago (one going across Laza and the other across Verin) leading to Ourense.\n\nOurense receives the pilgrims in the rural village of Seixalbo, a set of ethnographic value still retaining its medieval trace. From there, the Way enters the city from the south, going through Zamora Avenue and Progreso Street to As Burgas, the hot springs which every pilgrim must visit since the Middle Ages.

The Ribeira Sacra is the area north of the province around the banks of rivers Sil and Minho, known for its impressive natural wealth and heritage. Its name (meaning “Holy Riverbank”) comes from the Middle Ages, and has its origin in the number of monasteries that had been built in it, among which are San Esteban de Ribas de Sil, San Pedro de Rocas and Santa Cristina de Ribas de Sil. There is much to see, but above all you must visit river Sil’s canyons: from their viewpoints you can admire the spectacular landscape, and from a catamaran sailing the river you will appreciate their sheer monumentality.

From the Main Square, in the Historic Centre, A Chavasqueira thermal baths (the closest ones to the city centre) are just over two kilometres on foot; going there will take you a half hour. But if you want to get closer to Outariz and Burga de Canedo, the last pools of river Minho\'s Thermal Route, the distance increases to 7 kilometres. The most comfortable alternative is to use the Thermal Train, which will take you to the thermal area of Outariz through the river lane, stopping at all the pools and crossing the arches of the Old Bridge, in a 30-minute trip in which you will enjoy the beautiful views of Ourense.

Comfortable, quiet, safe… and with lots of activities to have a great time! Ourense is undoubtedly a destination that will delight the travelers with family, with many proposals designed for the children of the house, enjoying the outdoors or learning about the history and customs of the city while having fun. And don’t forget a good dip in thermal water!\n\nIf you visit the city in a weekend, on Sunday you should go to Carrileiros Railroad Park, where you can enter the exciting world of trains and even riding on a scale locomotive. The venue has a circuit of almost 500 metres of railway where the trains circulate, in a route with all possible details.

A feast of subversion and good humour, the Entroido (Carnival) is a very traditional celebration in Ourense, as it kept being held despite prohibitions in past times. The province concentrates up to seven carnivals declared of tourist interest, making the capital the perfect starting point to discover them. If you visit the city in February, ypu must wear a disguise, otherwise, you risk to have to pay for rounds at the bars, and you have to taste the typical product of these dates, the ears.

The feast of the nature par excellence, announcing the splendour of the flowers and the farewell of the cold winter. Of uncertain origin, this rite is celebrated since very remote times in several places of Galicia, although in Ourense it has remarkable and singular characteristics, besides being a local holiday. On the first Sunday of May, handmade sculptures of moss and flowers occupy the Alameda central promenade displaying traditional (pyramidal) or figurative shapes, always accompanied by songs: satirical verses on current issues that are traditionally sold in exchange for a tip.

The feast in honour of Saint Martin of Tours, patron of Ourense, announces the arrival of the popular Magostos, in which groups of friends and family gather around large bonfires to roast the first chestnuts and try the new wine. The party lasts all day and part of the night, always seasoned with roasted sausages, songs and a final toast with queimada, evoking ancient rites of purification. It is common to celebrate the Magostos in the mountains surrounding the city, especially Montealegre, although the urbanites can always go to the big bonfire that the City Council organizes in the Alameda Park. It is celebrated on November 11th.

The longest night of the year is celebrated in Ourense with a parade of pumpkins illuminated with candles through the streets of the Historic Centre. Although its best-known version is American Halloween, the truth is that Samhain is a feast of Celtic origins (in agricultural terms, the farewell of the long days of the summer) that in Galicia has been celebrated for centuries, although it was about to get lost. For some years in Ourense it has been celebrated with new forces, with workshops where girls and boys prepare the pumpkins with which they will then parade dressed as skeletons, ghosts, witches, etc. The celebrations extend all night and, as during Entroido, the disguises abound, as dark as possible.

Although Ourense does not celebrate its patron\'s feast until autumn, the Festivities take advantage of June\'s warmer weather and the celebration of Corpus Christi, a very traditional feast here. There are two weeks of festival in the city with non-stop activities: orchestras, concerts, parades, sports, children\'s activities and so on. The fireworks of its closing ceremony are indispensable, and for the most daring ones, the classic Ourense Rallye.

There are few places in Europe with so many products with denomination of origin as Ourense. This is especially evident in the case of wine: four of the five denominations that exist in Galicia are found in this province. A very long tradition that has its roots in the Roman presence and the monasteries, and which was already referred by the medieval King Alfonso X the Wise who sang the delights of the \"good wine from Ourense\".

Ourense concentrates the best of the different gastronomic cultures in Galicia: from the coast it adopted the taste for the octopus, and from the inland the taste for meats and homegrown vegetables. Many of the most renowned products of Galician gastronomy are produced here, several of them protected with denominations of origin.

If there is a place in the city where people converge naturally, especially on weekend nights, it is certainly \"Os Viños\" in the Historic Centre, the tapas area par excellence of Ourense. This set of streets, united at one end by Blacksmiths\' Square and ending around the Cathedral, concentrates plenty of bars, restaurants and taverns where to enjoy the gastronomy and wine tradition of Ourense, sharing snacks, tapas and songs in good company. Although there are more and more proposals for a complete dinner and menu à la carte, the tradition is still to try some snacks at the foot of the bar making short stops: as tradition says, a snack per bar.
Church of Holy Mary, Mother of God
The element that articulates the Historic Centre
Meet the Nymphs of As Burgas
Centre and heart of monumental Ourense
The entrance to the new millennium
Get lost in a maze of Stone and History
The last remain of a Franciscan convent
See the sunset from a Pre-Roman settlement

The history of the Cathedral of Ourense is a journey of more than 8 centuries of construction and alterations that have shaped its structure: a temple of Latin cross with influences of Compostela and Cistercian art, made in late Romanesque style with notes of Gothic. Its elevation is usually dated between the 12th and 13th centuries and is one of the main monuments of the city, around which the streets of the historic centre are articulated.

Monumental and majestic, Ourense's Cathedral still retains an air of the fortress that was in his past, which may be suspected from the towers and battlements of the southern facade. At the top stands out, for its spectacular height, the beautiful late Gothic dome, built in the 16th century.

Inside, with austere and elegant lines, the atmosphere of serenity and seclusion invites to walk around the ambulatory and its various chapels.

If we look closely to the northern gate, its authors have left a joke for posterity. We must find a character showing us his back. If we lower the view vertically from this figure to the ground we will see a small gap that remains curiously with water almost all year…

This Roman bridge is one of the historical landmarks of the city, linked to its origins. When it was built it was a strategic passage, the only point in many kilometres to cross river Minho. It was declared a Historic Monument in 1961. You must cross it while walking the Mozarabic Way – Via de la Plata to Santiago de Compostela.\n \nThe bridge also had a tower (appearing on the city\'s coat of arms) which was demolished in the 19th century. Attached to the old bridge, with which it forms a historic monument, is the chapel of Our Lady of Los Remedios.

You can not (or should not) leave Ourense without touching the water from these sources, one of the three “treasures” traditionally sung of the city: it comes from underground aquifers more than a kilometre deep and flows at +60°C. With these temperatures, it is not difficult to imagine the therapeutic uses which had over time. Its history dates back to the times of the Roman settlers.

This area is traditionally divided into three sections: the monumental fountain or "Burga de Abaixo"; the central esplanade, where the thermal pool is located; and the "Burga de Arriba".

On the lower level, you will find the recognizable silhouette of a Neoclassic fountain attributed to master Trillo. It consists of two side pipes and a pile carved with a finial in the centre, crowned by the coat of arms of the city. It was designed as a nymphaeum, a dwelling for nymphs, evoking the Roman past of the area which was already suspected back then. On one side is the "Fervedoiro", a square pond where you can see the water bubbling at boiling point.

For centuries, the Main Square has been the heart of the historic centre, and still is the main meeting point in the city. Bright, wide and arcaded, it is irregular in shape and has the distinction of being one of the few main squares in Europe with a slightly sloping floor.

The space is dominated by the facade of the City Hall, designed by Queralt, occupying the only side without arcades. Next to it stands the Old Bishop's Palace.

The other three sides are the arches that form the Promenade, a former lane for the aristrocracy reconverted nowadays into one of the downtown's liveliest areas with its terraces. Above it, the beautiful facades of noble houses from the 18th and 19th centuries with tiles.

In 1998 the Old Bridge was definitively closed to car traffic. The following year the City Council laid the foundation stone of this bridge, which would be inaugurated on September 1st, 2001. Its opening meant not only a considerable relief to city traffic, but immediately became a symbol of contemporary Ourense, the moving city that overlooks the new millennium.

A work of markedly avant-garde aesthetics, its was designed by architect Álvaro Varela. It features an unique elliptical shape, being especially curious its pedestrian walkway that rises 22 metres, leading to extraordinary viewpoints over river Minho.

Its construction created a curious wave in the waters of river Minho, the Millennium Wave, which has since been used to water sports.

Manor pits, thermal springs, museums or large temples such as the cathedral, one of the best examples of Romanesque throughout the Iberian Peninsula, are some of the ingredients that make Ourense a small big beauty; all of this located in a short number of streets, conforming the historical centre of the city.

The Praza do Ferro is a crossroad more than a square, for that reason it is also named "Cruz de Ferro". Here, it was celebrated the market of the old blacksmiths, where were sold farm implements, pots and pans came from all over Galicia.

 It is formed by a square almost triangular, delimited in the west by the arcades and ancient buildings. Also, we can see the palace built in the 16th century by Don Juan Fernandez de Boan and Landecho.

In the center of the square there is a beautiful Renaissance fountain, which was originally located in San Esteban de Ribas de Sil Monastery. It has sirens at its base, caryatids, eros and two eagles crowning it.

This square is considered one of the Galician historical cultural nuclei, because here were born or lived writers and scholars like Vicente Risco, Otero Pedrayo, Florentino López Cuevillas, Xoaquín Lorenzo "Xocas" and Eduardo Blanco Amor.

Originally belonging to a former Jesuit school, since 1767 it is part of the diocese as a parish church. Its facade, made by Brother Plácido Iglesias, is an archetype of Galician Baroque, combining sumptuousness, the use of curved lines and the play of light with the most typical details of Galician art: the use of granite, the giant order of columns, pinnacles or pediments with cross. Especially striking is its concave shape, a possible resource for greater monumentality despite the narrowness of the street, as St Euphemia’s Square is modern and subsequent to the church.\n\nThe interior, very austere, has a Latin cross floor with three longitudinal naves. A large Baroque altar presides over the church with the Christ of Hope in the centre.

This market square is the most important market of the city, and well worth a visit for its peculiarity. The building itself was built in 1929, and has more palatial and stately atmosphere than market. The main access is done by a monumental staircase. Inside you can find all kinds of fresh food stalls, mainly cheeses and dairy, butchers and fishmongers.

But the most peculiar of this market is the exterior: Formerly it was surrounded by vineyards, but they were flooded in 1945 when the Barbaña river overflowed, so they disappeared and the land was filled. Since then, small buildings have been built there, known as the "Rianxo". The exterior of the market is perfectly classified by zones, depending on the products sold: Bakeries are all together in one area, florists in another, vegetables in another and so on.

It opens from Monday to Saturday from 8 to 15h.

Small square in the place known in the Middle Ages as «Arcade Fountain», the former site of one of the gates of the city.\n\nA fountain of modern construction stands out, topped by a sculpture of children\'s themes by Antonio Faílde. In one of its sides you may see the chapel that gives it its name: Saints Cosmas and Damian. This 16th-century building houses one of the most curious museums, the Arturo Baltar exhibition space and Baltar\'s nativity scene: over a hundred figures of clay that recreate traditional scenes of the Galician countryside and the Ourense of yore.

In the 14th century, after the fire that destroyed the first Franciscan convent in the city, the order moved to this place on the side of Montealegre Hill, where they remained until the 19th century. In 1843 the old convent was transformed into infantry headquarters (until its closure in 1984), producing numerous reforms. The most significant of them was the move of the apse and front of the church to St Lazarus' Park, where it was rebuilt. The orphaned cloister can now be visited.

Declared a National Historic Monument in 1951, St Francis' Cloister has outlived its eventful history retaining the beauty of its 63 arches virtually untouched, all of them decorated with motifs of plants, animals and humans. They are distributed around a seemingly square floor: neither side has the same number of arches, which are supported by double columns except the first four and last four in each row.

In the south side we may find the Chapel of the Venerable Third Order, today transformed into a hostel for pilgrims, and the exhibition space where part of the funds of the Provincial Archaeological Museum are shown. The set comes complete with St Francis' Cemetery, located in the old convent's former orchard.

Of medieval origin, these gardens are nowadays one of the places that still retain the charm of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, with superb examples of Modernist architecture. Crossed by Progreso street, its upper half is called Bishop Cesáreo's Gardens.

Former site for the councils, which were the neighborhood meetings where the public affairs of the medieval city were discussed, it was also the municipal orchard planted with olive trees. The aesthetic ideal of the powerful local bourgeoisie was felt in the works of the architects of the time, Daniel Vázquez Gulías and Manuel Conde among others.

The lower Alameda, in turn, stands on the river Barbaña, at the end of a tree-lined promenade where there is a female sculpture by Luís Borrajo.

Enclosed urban park with unusual trees in these latitudes: it was originally a botanical garden, created in the mid-19th century by teachers from the neighbouring Otero Pedrayo Secondary School, who equipped it with trees and plants brought from the Botanical Garden in Madrid. The garden came to gather up to 200 species.

It is structured in three levels or terraces: the upper one (originally, the forest) stands out for its dense woodland and has a playground for children; the middle level is occupied by the traditional walk; and the bottom level is centered by a palm-lined promenade, a lush rose garden, a fountain and a pond. Surely we may find some peacocks in our journey.

The central promenade of these gardens is a traditional meeting place in the city; usually many of the concerts during the summer festivals are performed here. It also has a café with a terrace to rest in the shade of the banana trees.

Its facade, made in a restrained Baroque style, does not reveal the importance of this medieval church, located in the site of the previous cathedral of Ourense. The church was rebuilt in 1084 after its devastation, and again in 1772. It has three naves and three lanes framed by fluted pilasters. In the upper body, there are heraldic motifs, a pediment and two towers on the sides.

The church can't be understood without its monumental stairway, which connects the secluded Magdalene Square with the Main Square.

Inside, there is an altarpiece made of wood -in its natural colour- in Churrigueresque style. The statue of Holy Mary is taken out in procession on Holy Saturday and on Easter Sunday. This curious ritual evokes the conflicts that for years confronted the bishop and the municipal corporation in the city.

The current church was erected in 1722 on the initiative of bishop Marcelino Siuri, who increased the stonework. This explains why the bishop's palace is at its side.

Located at the foot of the temple, the Gate of Paradise was built along the lines of Santiago. The sculpture set, one of the gems of the Ourense Cathedral, dazzles with its suggestive, almost hypnotic polychromy.

The statues in the columns reproduce the prophets. Among them, we may find Daniel with a friendly smile. Also the apostles with their books. The central arch retains the 24 elders of the Apocalypse, musicians carrying instruments from that time that seem to interact with each other in a lively talk.

Leaning against the mullion there is a central statue of St. James. Above it, in a niche, we find a character on horseback, sword in hand. It is Saint Martin, patron of Ourense, who according to tradition in a winter day cut his cloak in half with his blade, offering it to a beggar.

On the walls, two anonymous paintings from the 18th century showing St Christopher and St Ildefonsus.

In the old street of shoemakers, Mr Santiago Sáez built a theatre. The year was 1830 and the new theatre was built in the fashion of the time, in Italian style, halfway between Baroque and Romanticism.\n\nCentre of Ourense\'s cultural life but also of the social and politic life, throughout its history the building underwent numerous transformations and refurbishments, such as that undertaken in 1915 to turn it into a cinema. In the 90s the city recovered this space after the major restoration which gave it its current design. Keeping the traditional elements, its dome incorporated frescoes by Xaime Quessada, and its design explains why the peanut gallery is called \"the paradise\" here.

Opened in 2005, the Auditorium occupies a privileged space in the city. It was built by architect José Manuel Casabella, who designed and adapted it to the steep slope with a curvilinear path that respects the surrounding streets. 

It is a versatile multipurpose space. It has three rooms and a two-floor underground parking. The lobbies are comfortably dimensioned to accommodate exhibitions and various cultural and social events.

They are well lit spaces with views over the city, through its glass facade.

The Ribeira Sacra is an area that includes the banks of the rivers Cabe, Sil and Miño, in the south zone of the province of Lugo and the north of the province of Ourense. The Ribeira Sacra is especially known for its natural and biological treasures, constituting a vast ecosystem of great variety and richness. The Sil canyons stand out for their spectacular landscape. This is an area in which the river runs encased through landscapes and mountains that have been described as extremely beautiful.

The canyons have viewpoints enabled to admire its impressive monumentality, as well as a catamaran open to the public that crosses the canyons from one to the other side.

This place is also known for the quality of its wines. The vineyards, which can be seen along the course of the river, are arranged in a system of stone steps, called terraces, along the bank, and date back to Roman times.

In addition to the spectacular landscapes, the Ribeira Sacra is also known for its spiritual past. The toponym \"Ribeira Sacra\" could come from the Middle Ages . It was thought that the origin of its denomination would be in the Latin \"Rivoira Sacrata\", that could respond to the great amount of monasteries and temples located in the monumental Canyons and steep slopes that line the area. The ancient monks probably selected this place as their house due to the natural peace that can still be breathed nowadays.\n\nOne of the most remarkable monasteries of Ourense is St. Pedro de Rocas, located in the municipality of Esgos.

In Galicia, the water becomes art. One example of this are the beautiful landscapes created the rivers waterfalls. Located in the municipality of Silleda, you can find the spectacular Fervenza do Toxa.

This archaeological site is essential to understand a fundamental part of the city\'s past. It combines historical values with natural ones, derived from a contour that not only retains a peculiar vegetation but enjoys a privileged location with stunning views over the city.\n\nFrom an archaeological perspective, Santomé stands out as one of the few examples in Spain where you can still see the coexistence, in time and space, of two very different cultures. In the highest part there are remains of a castro, a fortified settlement typical of the Celtic peoples of the Iron Age; in the plain, there is a customary Galician-Roman villa. Both date from the 1st century A.D., which shows how Roman modes and forms coexisted in perfect symbiosis with previous traditions, creating models that will survive long in rural Galicia.

Although not strictly a bridge, the road through Velle's hydroelectric plant and its dam are a common crossing point of river Minho, for both vehicles and pedestrians. Its construction in 1963 allowed to connect the neighbourhoods of O Vinteun and A Lonia.

Although it is only possible to cross the dam during daytime, it offers good views of the Velle waterfall. Its five water gates take the pushes of rivers Minho and Sil at the entrance of the city.

300 meters upstream, the Velle bridge was built in 1992, connecting the roads of Santigo and Monforte de Lemos.
Grilled meats, churrasco and Portuguese cod at the entrance of the Millennium Bridge
One of the most prestigious restaurants in Ourense
Located in one of the most visited areas of the historical center of the city. Well known for its Mexican homemade food
Galician homemade cuisine in the historic centre
Homemade cuisine in the old town
A piece of sea into the inland
Their specialties: broken egg pans and homemade croquettes
An original place, known for its ox mini burgers and with good views to the cathedral
A place to enjoy the flavours of Ourense
Wide menu of tapas in the heart of the Ferro Square
Tapas for all tastes, also vegan food
Possibly the best chocolate and churros in the city
A shopping centre with a varied number of restaurants and shops
A team of young people with the desire to create something different in Ourense
A space devoted to the best fish and meat
Its specialty: "El Completo", tortilla, bacon and croquette. Must stop in the old town
Galician cuisine in the heart of the historical centre
Friendly place in the old town
Its specialty: the "bombs" with meat or Arzúa cheese

Classic hotel a few metres from the shopping centre
Hotel of modern design, located in a natural environment but a step away from the city centre
Small hotel at a carefully restored building in the heart of the Historic Centre
In the city centre. Enjoy their anti-ox breakfast buffet and the fitness area with sauna and spa
Rooms with a view in one of the tallest buildings in the city
Modern rooms and suites with free Wi-Fi,gym and Turkish bath
A modern twist hotel, located in the commercial area of central Ourense
Charming family hotel in the historic centre of Ourense since 1941
A boutique hotel newly built on two historic buildings in the centre of Ourense
Central and friendly small hotel, you\'ll feel right at home
Small and cozy hotel located a few metres from Ourense Hospital
Mabu is the best located and closest hotel to the thermal resources of the city
Renovated in 2012, this hostel next to the train station has 20 rooms with TV, private bathroom and WiFi
Good deal tourist hostel, very close to the city centre, ideal for young travellers who want to discover the city

The Princess hotel is located in the centre of Ourense, in one of the main streets of the city and just a few metres from the Paseo shopping street, leading directly to the historic centre.

Hotel services include a cafe and a restaurant, free Wi-Fi throughout the hotel and laundry service. Guests can shop at any of the stores located inside.

In its accommodation, the Princess hotel has 56 rooms equipped with air conditioner, satellite TV and optional hydromassage.

Eurostars Auriense is a hotel with modern design. It has 134 fully equipped rooms and offers facilities with meeting rooms, business center, garden and outdoor pool.\n\nA short distance away is the Montealegre Golf Club, with magnificent views of its surroundings. It offers an attractive 18-hole course with a high level of both physical and technical demand.

With a prime location in the historic centre of Ourense, overlooking the square Eironciño dos Cabaleiros, the Hotel Irixo occupies a recently renovated building, two minutes away from the Cathedral and five from As Burgas. Nearby you can find shops and all kinds of lesiure and entertainment.

Its 13 rooms are equipped with heating, TV and private bathroom and TV. By its design and location, the Hotel Irixo becomes a fantastic option to enjoy the city, its culture and its history.

Pet friendly hotel.
 
Bicycles are allowed.

NH Ourense is a modern hotel in the city centre, just 10 minutes from the hot springs of river Minho and within a walking distance of the historic area. In addition to the 21 Standard rooms and 8 Standard Single, the hotel offers 9 elegant and comfortable suites that are easily adapted to families and groups of up to 4 members.\n\nAll rooms are attractively decorated with elegant Italian furniture, wooden floors and modern design, plus they have a variety of thoughtful amenities: complimentary Internet connection (WiFi), satellite TV, mini-bars and comfortable mattresses, among other.

Located in the emblematic building of La Torre in the centre of Ourense, the Gran Hotel San Martin dominates St Lazarus\' Park. It has 90 rooms, including a presidential suite, equipped with air conditioner, satellite TV, Wi-Fi and clothes-rack and trouser press.\n\nIn the centre of Ourense, a few metres from the start of Paseo street, where one of the main shopping areas is located, the hotel location facilitates the movement of its customers for the main tourist and leisure spots of the city.

The Francisco II is located in the city centre of Ourense , just 50 metres from St Lazarus' Park and one of the main shopping streets of the city: Paseo. It has 55 rooms and a cafeteria to meet all the needs of its customers, with an extensive menu of fast food.

The hotel has Wi-Fi, gym, Turkish bath, a hair salon and business center.

Up to 4 conference rooms, the Francisco II hotel offers a catering service for events, conferences and meetings.

Its 35 rooms, double and single, are fully equipped to meet the needs of customers, who will find in this hotel the perfect place for an urban visit, a business trip or a family trip to Ourense. It has its own cafeteria for snacks or something sweet.\n\nBicycles are admitted.

Run by the same family since 1941, you will find a professional and friendly service where you can enjoy the tranquility that give our rooms.\n \nThe hotel has 15 comfortable and functional rooms, 11 doubles, 3 with double beds and 1 single, with possibility of adding an extra bed or cot. Some feature landscaped balconies. They have private bathroom, shower cubicle, hairdryer and toiletries.

The Carrís Cardenal Quevedo is strategically located in one of the most central and busy streets of the city, a few metres from the historic centre of Ourense, St Lazarus Park, the train station and river Minho. It is right next to the shopping and entertainment district.\n\nIts modern facilities make it a place with charm and sophistication. Even the smallest detail was designed to give the best customer service, with 39 rooms highlighting the space, comfort and design. It offers fully equipped meeting rooms and a restaurant with a menu with typical local products.

Small hotel in the centre of the city, known for its attentive service and family atmosphere.

It has 32 rooms equipped with flat screen HD TV, heating and telephone.

Pets are allowed on request.

A team of professionals, always attentive to your needs, will welcome you in a nice family atmosphere paying special attention to detail. From the decoration, modern and functional, to a home-made and delicate cuisine, this hotel is devoted (since 1996) to offer the well-known Galician cordiality and hospitality.\n\nAmong the features of this hotel stand out the free parking for customers, internet access via WiFi, air conditioner, laundry and fax.

Just one kilometer from the Hot Springs of A Chavasqueira and less than two kilometers from the famous Hot Springs of Outariz.

Well connected with the most tourist areas of the city and a few minutes from the centre.

Attention, comfort and facilities at the best price.

Renovated in 2012, La Rotonda hostel is located a few metres from the train station and the main tourist attraction of the city: river Minho\'s Thermal Route.\n\nThe hostel has 10 rooms facing out, all equipped with aprivate bathroom, heating, a LED 24″ TV and free WiFi. Services as its 24-hour reception desk, the daily newspapers, private parking or cocktail bar will make your stay more comfortable and enjoyable, all in a family atmosphere.

Grelo Hostel is a stop along the way, a place where you can regain strength before continuing with the hard pilgrimage towards Santiago de Compostela. The starting point for an unforgettable holiday discovering Ourense, its province and the rest of inland Galicia.

The Grelo Hostel has 32 beds in shared rooms. The reservation includes breakfast for each guest every day. There is a common room with tables where you can eat, organize your trip or hang out. The common area has vending machines. Free WiFi access in all rooms and public areas of the hostel.

It features laundry facilities and parking for bicycles.
